guicomponents
Class GButton

java.lang.Object
  guicomponents.GComponent
      guicomponents.GButton
All Implemented Interfaces:
GConstants, java.lang.Comparable
public class GButton
extends GComponent

This class is the Button component. The button face can have either text or an image or both just pick the right constructor. Three types of event can be generated :-
PRESSED RELEASED CLICKED
To simplify event handling the button only fires off CLICKED events if the mouse button is pressed and released over the button face (the default behaviour).
Using 

button1.fireAllEvents(true);
enables the other 2 events for button button1. A PRESSED event is created if the mouse button is pressed down over the button face, the CLICKED event is then generated if the mouse button is released over the button face. Releasing the button off the button face creates a RELEASED event.
The image file can either be a single image which is used for all button states, or be a composite of 3 images (tiled horizontally) which are used for the different button states OFF, OVER and DOWN in which case the image width should be divisible by 3.
A number of setImages(...) methods exist to set button state images, these can be used once the button is created.

Author:
Peter Lager

GButton

               java.lang.String imgFile,
               int nbrImages,
               int x,
               int y,
               int width,
               int height)
Create a button with image only. Height and width may increase depending on image size.

Parameters:
theApplet -
imgFile - filename of image to use on the button
nbrImages - number of images in the film strip normally 1 or 3 (OFF OVER DOWN)
x - horz position of button
y - vert position
width - minimum width of button
height - minimum height of button

               java.lang.String imgFile,
               int nbrImages,
               int x,
               int y,
               int width,
               int height)
Create a button with both text and image. Height and width may increase depending on initial text length and image size.

Parameters:
theApplet -
text - text appearing on the button
imgFile - filename of image to use on the button
nbrImages - number of images in the film strip normally 1 or 3 (OFF OVER DOWN)
x - horz position of button
y - vert position
width - minimum width of button
height - minimum height of button

setImages

public void setImages(java.lang.String imgFile,
                      int nbrImages)
Specify the image file that contains the image{s} to be used for the button's state.
This image may be a composite of 1 to 3 images tiled horizontally.

Parameters:
imgFile -
nbrImages - in the range 1 - 3

setText

public void setText(java.lang.String text)
Set the text to appear on the button. This does nothing if the parameter is null or an empty string.
If the button has an image with CENTER allignment it is made LEFT alligment.

Overrides:
setText in class GComponent
Parameters:
text - the text to set with alignment

setFont

public void setFont(java.lang.String fontname,
                    int fontsize)
Set the font & size for the button increasing height and width of the button if necessary to display text.
It will not shrink if the font size is decreased.

Overrides:
setFont in class GComponent
Parameters:
fontname - the name of the font to use (if not available use default font)
fontsize - the font size to use

setFont

public void setFont(java.lang.String fontname,
                    int fontsize,
                    boolean resize)
Set the font and size for the button. If resize is true then the button size will be increased if necessary to display text.

Parameters:
fontname - the name of the font to use (if not available use default font)
fontsize - the font size to use
resize -

setImageAlign

Sets the position of the image in relation to the button text provided the text horizontal alignment is GAlign.LEFT or GAlign.RIGHT

Parameters:
imgAlign - either GAlign.LEFT or GAlign.RIGHT

fireAllEvents

public void fireAllEvents(boolean all)
If the parameter is true all 3 event types are generated, if false only CLICKED events are generated (default behaviour).

Parameters:
all -

mouseEvent

public void mouseEvent(java.awt.event.MouseEvent event)
All GUI components are registered for mouseEvents.
When a button is clicked on a GButton it generates 3 events (in this order) mouse down, mouse up and mouse pressed.
If you only wish to respond to button click events then you should test the event type e.g. 
        void handleButtonEvents(GButton button) {
          if(button == btnName && button.eventType == GButton.CLICKED){
        // code for button click event
    }

Where 
btnName
is the GButton identifier (variable name)

Overrides:
mouseEvent in class GComponent
